Description: Qenherkhepeshef's funerary headrest: the limestone headrest is decorated with incised apotropaic figures of mythical animals and the domestic deity Bes. It is inscribed with incised hieroglyphs, originally painted blue, recording prayers in Middle Egyptian. One end is damaged.
Curator's comments: The material and inscription indicate that it is a funerary item, rather than a headrest that was used by Qenherkhepshef in life. Bibliography: B. Porter & R. Moss, 'Topographical Bibliography of Ancient Egyptian Hieroglyphic Texts, Reliefs and Paintings' I (Parts 2) (Oxford: Clarendon Press), 748; K.A. Kitchen, 'Ramesside Inscriptions' 7 (Oxford, 1989), 200; M. Bierbrier and R.B. Parkinson, 'Hieroglyphic texts from Egyptian stelae, etc., in the British Museum' 12 (London, 1993) pl. 43; 'Les artistes de Pharaon : Deir el-Médineh et la Vallée des Rois', (Paris, 2002), pp.132-133 [73]. G. Pinch, Magic in Ancient Egypt (London 1994), fig.21.
Bibliographic references: Parkinson 1999 / Cracking Codes: The Rosetta Stone and Decipherment (69)
Bierbrier 1993 / Hieroglyphic texts from Egyptian stelae, etc., in the British Museum, Part 12. (Pl.42-43)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2010/11 Oct-Mar, Leiden, National Museum Of Antiquities, Egyptian Magic 2015-2016 27 May-10th Apr, Québec, Le Musée de la Civilisation, Egyptian Magic.
